warning.para: To avoid property damage or personal injury, or both, possibly death, do not perform any service on the fuel system in the presence of open flames, intense heat, sparks, lighted cigarettes, or similar hazards in your work area.

geninfo.para: Proper fuel tank preventive maintenance is required to maintain maximum engine performance. Specifically, vehicle operators should:

item.para: Use only a known good quality of Grade No. 1-D or Grade No. 2-D diesel fuel.
Purchase only from reputable suppliers who sell large amounts of diesel fuel.

A premium grade of Grade No. 1-D or Grade No. 2-D diesel fuel that meets Engine Manufacturer's Association (EMA) spec. FQP-1A may also be used. It has a minimum Cetane number of 50 that provides better cold weather performance and enhanced lubricity characteristics for improved fuel system durability.
Keep fuel tanks topped off with fuel to reduce condensation due to temperature and humidity changes.
If vehicles are operated infrequently, consider adding an algaecide and a bactericide to the fuel to retard microbial growth.
If on-site fuel storage and dispensing equipment is used:
Keep storage tanks full and use up fuel frequently (diesel fuel degrades over time).
Consider adding an algaecide and a bactericide to the fuel to retard microbial growth.
Use a high quality filter in the fuel dispensing line.
Inspect vehicle fuel tanks periodically for evidence of contamination. Particularly inspect for rust in steel tanks.

svcprocinfo.para: If interior fuel tank contamination is found, thorough steam cleaning is recommended. Steel tanks with fine interior surface rust can be steam cleaned. However, steel fuel tanks should be replaced if interior flaking or deep pitting due to rust is found.

step1.para: International Engines require Grade No. 1-D or Grade No. 2-D diesel fuel, with or without EMA spec. FQP-1A designation.
International Engines require fuel with a minimum Cetane number of 45.
International Engines require that fuel sulfur content be no higher than 0.05%.
Fuels sold as heating or furnace oil must not be used in International Engines.
Diesel fuels blended with used engine oil, gasoline, gasohol or alcohol must not be used in International Engines.
See Figures below on the use of Biodiesel fuels in International Engines.
Refer to other diesel engine manufacturers fuel requirements for fuels to be used in their respective engines.
